citations.narrative:
On 6/30/2022, a Vervet (#2226) died while under anesthesia during a surgical procedure to implant a headcap.
Anesthesia was administered and monitored by the Attending Veterinarian (AV) and a Research Assistant (RA) during
initial surgery preparation and the first hour of the surgery. At that point the AV departed leaving the RA in charge of
anesthesia with instructions to contact the AV if any issues arose. 25 minutes later the Vervet’s head became dislodged
from the apparatus that kept it stable during surgery. The head was quickly replaced into the apparatus. The lead surgeon
asked the RA to confirm the status of the endotracheal tube, and correct placement was assumed due to “frosting” or
appearance of vapor within the tube walls. About 15 minute later monitoring devices began to register declining blood
oxygen levels and the pulse derived from the ECG monitor was lost. The RA believed these were possible mechanical
failures and began monitoring heart rate using a stethoscope. Surgery was concluded about 1 ½ hours later and the AV
returned. Once the Vervet was taken off the ventilator, there was no spontaneous respiration, and heart sounds could not
be heard using the stethoscope. The Vervet was pronounced dead moments later. The facility believes that the
endotracheal tube may have become dislodged during surgery leading to hypoxia and eventual cardiac injury. It is the
opinion of both the AV and RA that the RA did not have sufficient training to properly respond to the situation.
The health and wellbeing of animals, especially during complex surgical procedures requiring prolonged and properly
monitored and regulated anesthesia, depends on staff that have the proper training and experience to perform their
duties. It is the responsibility of the research facility to ensure that all scientists, research assistants, and other personnel
involved in animal care, treatment, and use are qualified to perform their duties. The RA in this incident is no longer
administering or monitoring anesthesia unsupervised and is receiving additional training.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the attending veterinarian.
